item.description:
Please read the section on mandatory equipment carefully!

This hike enters the Presidential-Range Dry River Wilderness.  Therefore, group size is capped at a maximum of 10 people per USFS regulations.

While only 5.0 miles round-trip, the elevation gain on this hike is 2140'!  The Davis Path is a consistent moderate grade from the time we cross the first river until we reach the ridgeline right below the summit.  If the weather cooperates, the views from the summit are spectacular.  Mount Washington seems close enough to touch, and Mounts Resolution and Stairs are prominent in the foreground.  This is a beautiful hike.

The total distance will be 5.0 miles and we'll gain 2140 feet in elevation. Book time is just under 5 hours.

This being winter, we will need to start promptly at 9:30 AM. We will also hike at a comfortable but steady pace. We will have lunch at the summit of Mount Crawford.

Also, please be aware that conditions are quite variable in the winter. Conditions may require us to forgo the summit. To quote Ed Viesturs, "Reaching the summit is optional. Getting down is mandatory."

Please note that dogs are not permitted on this hike.

Details

What: Mount Crawford
Distance: 5.0 miles round trip
Elevation Gain: 2140'
Difficulty: Moderate
Pace: Moderate.
Exposure: Significant exposure for about 30' on the summit ridge.
Book Time: 5 hours.

Is This Hike for Me?

This hike will be at amoderate pace under winter conditions. Expect ice and deep snow. The trails are relatively sheltered however expect windy conditions on and near the summit. Expect one significant stream crossings. While there should be thick ice bridges this time of year, that's not a guarantee. Stream crossings can be tricky in winter. We will keep the group together throughout the hike. Therefore, please plan to hike at a pace that will be comfortable for everyone. We will gain about 2140' during the hike. Expect a very steady grade throughout the hike. The views are spectacular from the summit. Weather conditions and time constraints will be monitored throughout the hike. Those conditions may result in a decision to turn back before the summit should safety become an issue.

To participate you should:

  • Be comfortable hiking UPHILL at about 1.5 to 2.0 miles per hour at a 20% incline for about 3 miles.
  • Be comfortable walking at least 6 miles on uneven terrain including ice and deep snow.
  • Have sturdy winter hiking boots suitable for cold weather. No Sneakers or summer boots!
  • Have rain, snow, and wind protection. No Ponchos!
  • Be able to carry at least 2 liters of water. (Remember, 1 liter weighs 2 pounds!)
  • Be in good physical condition.

Weather and Trail Conditions

Microspikes and Snowshoes - I fully expect to need some form of traction on this hike. At least Microspikes will be necessary. If you have snowshoes, you should bring them as well. While we will not know for certain if we need them, snowshoes should be a standard part of your winter pack this time of year. If you don't have them, you may rent them at EMS or REI.

Boots - A pair of winter hiking boots is mandatory. You will be hiking in snow for over 5-hours, so you cannot get away with your summer hiking boots in January or February. You do NOT need plastic boots for general hiking anywhere in NH, but you WILL need waterproof winter boots comfort rated to at least -30 degrees. (No, we don't typically encounter those temperatures, but boots with that rating will keep you warm while you're having your lunch on snow or ice.) Remember, you will be spending some time standing or sitting around during brief breaks, summit views, taking pictures, or having lunch. Warm winter boots will keep you comfortable and safe.

Water - Finally, you see the note below that your water must be in wide-mouth plastic bottles. It is time to put your hydration systems - e.g. Camelbak's - away for the winter. While they do sell insulated tubes for the hydration systems, quite frankly they do not work. The entrance to the tube where it connects to the bladder still freezes, leaving you with a bladder full of inaccessible water. Therefore, unless it is unseasonably warm for this hike, you'll need to carry water the old fashioned way. Be sure to get wide mouth bottles and be sure to carry them upside down. (Water freezes from the top down.)

Mandatory Equipment List as of 30 January 2011.
This list could change based on trail conditions just prior to the hike.


  • Microspikes or Hillsounds. (See note below.)
  • Snowshoes
  • Synthetic shirt and waterproof pants. No cotton. No jeans.
  • Sturdy Winter Hiking Boots suitable for cold weather. No Sneakers or summer boots.
  • Rain / Wind Jacket with hood. No Ponchos.
  • Warm fleece layer.
  • Warm gloves or preferably mittens. (2 pair is strongly recommended.)
  • Warm fleece or wool hat.
  • Balaclava
  • Sunglasses
  • 2 liters Water in wide-mouth bottles. No hydration systems!
  • Headlamp
  • Spare Lithium batteries for Headlamp. Bring Lithium, not Alkaline batteries.
  • Trail Snacks suitable for freezing weather. (You don't want something that turns into a rock when frozen.)
  • Lunch

Optional Gear:

  • Hiking Poles - strongly recommended
  • Gaiters - strongly recommended
  • Camera / Binoculars

     

    No Jeans, Sneakers, or Cotton clothing on the hike! Since it is winter, this will be strictly enforced.

    Carpool Option

    I don't have a carpool setup for this since I'll be driving up the night before. If you wish to arrange a carpool, please use the comments section to coordinate with other hikers.

    Dining Options

    Dinner

    We will plan to stop at either Fabians or The Muddy Moose for dinner after the hike.

    Directions to Trailhead

    From Providence, RI:

    Please allow 4 hours travel time from Providence


    • Take Route 95 North.
    • Take Route 93 North to NH.
    • Take Exit 35 (Route 3 North) towards Twin Mountain.
    • Turn Right in Twin Mountain onto Route 302.
    • The Davis Path Trailhead will be on your left about 20 miles down.

     

    Trails and Other Info

    I will send a detailed trail map to those that RSVP Yes.

    Our route will follow the Davis Path to the summit of Mount Crawford.  We will return the same way.

     

    Contact Information

    I will provide my cell phone number along with a link to a detailed trail map to all "YES" RSVPs the week of the hike. I strongly encourage you to call me if you have any questions about the hike or the gear required.

    Note about Yak Trax

    Yak Trax recently released a style of traction support similar to Microspikes and Hillsounds. I have received three separate reports of these new Yak Trax failing. Two of those situations resulted in falls. Since three separate hikers have recently found them unreliable, they are not considered suitable traction devices for hikes that I lead up north. Apologies to anyone that purchased Yak Trax, however your safety and the safety of the group as a whole is paramount.

    For now, the following devices are considered suitable traction options for hiking up north. Note that neither Hillsound Trail Crampons nor Katoola Microspikes are a substitute for full crampons in all conditions:

    Hillsound Trail Crampons
    Katoola Microspikes
    full Crampons (numerous brands)

    Liability Waiver
